post0.title: Is the
post0.content: About . This notebook explain how to fit the Italian open-data about the spread of #covid19 using a Susceptible-Infectious-Recovered (SIR) model. . Data fitting is modeled and solved using Constrained Optimization via Pyomo and IPOPT. . Important: I am neither a medical doctor nor an epidemiologist. This post is only about a didactic example of fitting open-data via Mathematical Optimization. . The SIR model: The Elegance of Simplicity . The SIR model ... . Constrained Optimization: Yes, SIR! . Is the Curve Flattening? . Charts made with Altair remain interactive. Example charts taken from this repo, specifically this notebook. .

page1.title: About Me
page1.content: About me . The views expressed on this blog are mine and do not necessarily reflect the views of my employers. . You can find my personal offical web pages at the following links: . My Academic Home Page . | My Publications . | . Credits . This blog started in 2012 after several discussions with my friend and coauthor Stefano Coniglio, who always proofreads my posts. Though I have not convinced him to write any guest post yet, he is a contributor of this blog: thanks Stefano! . Another friend and coauthor that supports this blog is Marco Chiarandini. I do not know when he finds the time to proofread my posts, but he does, with the same seriousness as if he were reviewing a paper: thanks Marco! . Sponsorships . I do not accept any web marketing advertisement on this web site. . However, you can offer me coffee and brioche or pizza capricciosa through paypal. . FastPages . This site is built with fastpages. .
